title: Main Method Signature
description: Identify the error in the main method signature.
explanation: The main method must be `static` to be the entry point of the application (`public static void main`).

title: Primitive Types
description: Is `String` a primitive type in Java?
explanation: No, `String` is a reference type (Object), not a primitive type like `int` or `boolean`.

title: Case Sensitivity
description: Find the syntax error related to case sensitivity.
explanation: Java is case-sensitive. `Number` and `number` are different identifiers. `number` is not declared.

title: Array Index
explanation: Yes, Java arrays are 0-indexed, so the first element is at index 0.

title: Variable Scope
explanation: Variable `x` is declared inside the `if` block and is not accessible outside of it.

title: Multiple Inheritance
description: Does Java support multiple inheritance of classes?
explanation: No, Java does not support multiple inheritance of classes (a class cannot extend more than one class). It supports implementing multiple interfaces.

title: Const Keyword
explanation: `const` is a reserved keyword in Java but is not used. Use `final` to define constants.

title: Interface Methods
description: Are interface methods public by default?
explanation: Yes, methods in an interface are implicitly `public` and `abstract` (except static/default methods).

title: Abstract Class Instantiation
explanation: Abstract classes cannot be instantiated directly using `new`.

title: Break Statement
explanation: Yes, `break` terminates the loop largely immediately.

title: String Comparison
explanation: Using `==` compares object references, not content. Use `s1.equals(s2)` for content comparison.

title: Constructor Return Type
description: Do constructors have a return type?
explanation: Strictly speaking, if you add a return type (like `void`), it becomes a regular method, not a constructor. The code is syntactically correct but logic is false (it's not a constructor). Question asks 'Do constructors have a return type?'. Explanation: No. The snippet actually shows a method named Car, which is valid code but confusing. `isCodeCorrect: true`.

title: Final Variable Assignment
explanation: A `final` variable cannot be reassigned once initialized.

title: Boolean Values
description: Can you use 1 and 0 for booleans?
explanation: No, Java does not treat 1 and 0 as booleans. You must use `true` or `false`.

title: Switch Statement Type
explanation: Java `switch` statements do not support `boolean` values. They support int, char, byte, short, String (Java 7+), and enums.

title: Static Method Access
description: Can static methods access instance variables?
explanation: No, static methods belongs to the class and cannot access instance variables (non-static fields) directly without an object reference.

title: Method Overloading Return Type
codeSnippet:
public int foo() { return 1; }
public void foo() { }
explanation: Methods cannot be overloaded solely by return type. Parameter lists must differ.

title: Try Catch Finally
explanation: Yes, `finally` block executes even if there is a return in `try` (unless System.exit is called).

title: Private Access
explanation: `x` is private in class A and cannot be accessed directly from class B.

title: Super Constructor
explanation: Yes, if used, `super()` must be the very first statement in the constructor.

title: Interface Field
description: Identify the error in interface field assignment.
explanation: Fields in an interface are implicitly `public static final`. They cannot be reassigned.

title: This Keyword
description: Can `this` be used in static context?
explanation: No, `this` refers to the current instance, which doesn't exist in a static context.

title: Uninitialized Local Variable
explanation: Local variables must be initialized before use. `x` has no default value.

title: Default Access Modifier
explanation: No, there is no `default` keyword for classes access. Default (package-private) is achieved by omitting a modifier. `default` is used in interfaces or switch.

title: ArrayList Primitive
explanation: Generics in Java only support reference types. Use `Integer` instead of primitive `int`.

title: Runnable Interface
explanation: No, `Runnable` only has a `run()` method. `Thread` has `start()`.

title: Return in Void
explanation: A method with `void` return type cannot return a value.

title: Enhanced For Loop
description: Can you modify the collection during enhanced for-loop?
explanation: Modifying a collection while iterating with an enhanced for-loop usually throws `ConcurrentModificationException`.

title: Char Literals
explanation: Character literals must use single quotes `'A'`. Double quotes denote a String.

title: NullPointerException
explanation: Strictly speaking, `throw null` causes a `NullPointerException` at runtime. The statement itself compiles but immediately crashes. Is it 'Correct'? It's a bug pattern, often marked incorrect in reviews.

title: Inheritance Cycle
codeSnippet:
class A extends B {}
class B extends A {}
explanation: Cyclic inheritance involving `A` is not allowed.

title: Package Declaration
description: Must package be the first statement?
explanation: Yes, if present, the `package` declaration must be the very first statement (ignoring comments).

title: New Interface
explanation: `List` is an interface and cannot be instantiated directly. Use `ArrayList` or `LinkedList`.

title: Garbage Collection
explanation: No/Yes nuance: It *suggests* garbage collection, but does not guarantee/force immediate execution. However, the code snippet is correct syntax. The description question 'Does it force?' -> Answer is No.

title: Float Literal
explanation: `3.14` is a `double` literal by default. To assign to `float`, use suffix `f`: `3.14f`.

title: Var Keyword
explanation: No, `var` (Local Variable Type Inference) is only valid for local variables with initializers, not fields.

title: Do While Semicolon
explanation: A `do-while` loop must end with a semicolon after the condition: `while (x < 10);`.

title: String Immutability
explanation: Yes, String objects are immutable. The variable `s` is reassigned to point to a new String object "b", but the object "a" is not changed.

title: Casting Object
description: Identify the class cast error potential.
codeSnippet:
Object o = new String("A");
Integer i = (Integer) o;
explanation: Runtime `ClassCastException`. `o` holds a `String`, which cannot be cast to `Integer`.

title: Transient Keyword
explanation: Yes, `transient` fields are skipped during object serialization.

title: Break Label
explanation: `loop2` is not defined or visible. You can only break to an enclosing label (like `loop1`).

title: Method Local Inner Class
description: Can you have a class inside a method?
explanation: Yes, local classes can be defined within a method block.

title: Constructor Name
explanation: Constructors must define the exact name of the class (case-sensitive). `myClass` vs `MyClass`. This is treated as a method with missing return type.

title: Abstract Method Body
description: Can abstract methods have a body?
explanation: No, abstract methods cannot have a body (implementation). They must end with a semicolon.

title: Enum Instantiation
codeSnippet:
enum Color { RED }
Color c = new Color();
explanation: Enums cannot be instantiated using `new`. Use the defined constants like `Color.RED`.

title: Map Duplicate Keys
explanation: It allows putting the same key twice, but it *overwrites* the previous value. Keys are unique. The snippet is correct code.

title: Import Star
description: Find the import error (if any) - actually just bad practice.
explanation: Importing two classes with the same name (`List`) creates ambiguity. You must use the fully qualified name for at least one.

title: Volatile Keyword
explanation: No, `volatile` ensures visibility of changes across threads, but `count++` is not atomic (read-modify-write).

title: Array Length
codeSnippet:
int[] arr = new int[5];
int len = arr.length();
explanation: Arrays have a `length` property, not a method. Use `arr.length`.

title: Math Class
explanation: Yes, `java.lang.Math` is `final` and cannot be subclassed.

title: Exception in Signature
explanation: Checked exceptions (like `IOException`) must be declared in the method signature using `throws`, or handled with try-catch.

title: Object Class
description: Is `Object` the superclass of all classes?
explanation: Yes, every class in Java implicitly extends `java.lang.Object`.

title: Continue in Switch
explanation: `continue` cannot be used directly inside a `switch` statement (unless inside a loop within the switch).

title: String Pool
description: Does `new String()` use the string pool?
explanation: No/Yes nuance: The literal "abc" is in the pool, but `new String` creates a *new* object on the heap, bypassing the pool for the variable `s`. The code is correct. Question: 'Does it use pool (for strict reference)?'. Result is a heap object.

title: Interface Method Body
explanation: Interface methods cannot have bodies unless they are `default` or `static` (Java 8+).

title: Final Class
description: Can you extend a final class?
codeSnippet:
final class A {}
class B extends A {}
explanation: No, a `final` class cannot be subclassed.

title: Duplicate Case
explanation: Duplicate case labels (`case 1`) are not allowed in a switch statement.

title: Generic Array
description: Can you create an array of generics?
explanation: No, you cannot create arrays of parameterized types (generic array creation) due to type erasure.

title: Unreachable Code
explanation: Statements after a `return` statement are unreachable and cause a compile-time error.

title: Method Overriding
codeSnippet:
class A { private void run(){} } 
class B extends A { private void run(){} }
explanation: You can define a method with the same name, but it is *not* overriding (no polymorphism). It's just a new method. The code is technically correct/valid (it compiles), but it's not overriding.

title: Void Variable
explanation: `void` is not a type for variables. It is only a return type.

title: Local Static
description: Can you have static variables in methods?
explanation: No, local variables cannot be declared `static` in Java.

title: Class Access Modifier
explanation: Top-level classes cannot be `private` or `protected`. They can only be `public` or default (package-private).

title: Main Method Return
codeSnippet: public static int main(String[] args) { return 0; }
explanation: You *can* define a method named main returning int, but it will NOT be treated as the application entry point by the JVM (which expects void). Code is valid, but logic as 'entry point' is false. As strict code? True.

title: Assignment in If
explanation: `x = 10` is an assignment, which evaluates to `int` 10. `if` requires a `boolean`. Unlike C++, int is not coerced to boolean.

title: Byte Range
explanation: No, `byte` is signed 8-bit, range -128 to 127. 128 is too large.

title: Abstract Final
explanation: A class cannot be both `abstract` (meant to be extended) and `final` (cannot be extended).

title: Instanceof Null
explanation: Snippet is valid code. The result `b` will be `false` (null is not an instance of anything).

title: Implements Class
codeSnippet:
class A {}
class B implements A {}
explanation: You `extends` a class, you don't `implements` it. `implements` is for interfaces.

title: Char Arithmetic
explanation: Yes, `char` is a numeric type (16-bit unsigned). They behave like integers in arithmetic.

title: Double Catch
explanation: `IOException` is a subclass of `Exception`. It is already caught by the first block. Subclasses must be caught *before* superclasses.

title: String Switch
explanation: Yes, since Java 7, `switch` supports String objects.

title: Static This
codeSnippet:
static int x = 5;
static void set(int x) { this.x = x; }
explanation: `this` cannot be used in a static method. Use the class name `ClassName.x = x`.

title: Labelled Break
description: Can you break to a label?
explanation: Yes, labeled `break` continues execution after the labeled block (exiting it).

title: Array Negative Size
description: Identify the runtime behavior possibility (or logic error).
explanation: Throws `NegativeArraySizeException` at runtime (valid syntax but runtime error).

title: Covariant Return Type
codeSnippet:
class A { Object get() { return null; } }
class B extends A { String get() { return ""; } }
explanation: Yes, Java supports covariant return types (overriding method can return a subtype).

title: Private Interface Method
explanation: Private methods in interfaces were added in Java 9. Before that, it's an error.

title: Final Method Overriding
description: Can you override a final method?
codeSnippet:
class A { final void run(){} }
class B extends A { void run(){} }
explanation: No, `final` methods cannot be overridden.

title: Implicit Float Cast
explanation: `1.0` is a double. Assigning double to float requires explicit cast `(float) 1.0` or suffix `1.0f`.

title: Diamond Operator
explanation: Yes, Java 7 introduced the diamond operator `<>` to infer generic types.

title: Missing Interface Method
codeSnippet:
interface A { void run(); }
class B implements A {}
explanation: Concrete class `B` must implement the abstract method `run()` from interface `A`, or be declared `abstract`.

title: Try with Resources
explanation: Yes, classes implementing `AutoCloseable` are automatically closed at the end of the `try` block.

title: Extends Interface
codeSnippet:
interface A {}
interface B implements A {}
explanation: Interfaces `extends` other interfaces. They do not `implements` them.

title: Synchronized Block
explanation: No, synchronizing on `null` throws `NullPointerException`.

title: Non-Static Main
explanation: The main method must be `static` to launch the application.

title: Native Keyword
explanation: Yes, `native` keyword indicates the method is implemented in native code (JNI).

title: Duplicate Method
codeSnippet:
void test(int x) {}
int test(int y) { return y; }
explanation: Duplicate method. Parameter names don't change the signature; types do. Both take `(int)`, so they conflict.

title: Protected Access
description: Is `protected` accessible in subclass in different package?
explanation: Yes, `protected` members are accessible to subclasses in different packages (via inheritance).

title: Enum Inheritance
explanation: Enums are implicitly final and extend `java.lang.Enum`. You cannot explicitly extend classes.

title: Strictfp
explanation: Yes, `strictfp` ensures strict floating-point calculations reproducibility.

title: Increment String
explanation: The `++` operator does not work on Strings.

title: Anonymous Class
codeSnippet: Runnable r = new Runnable() { public void run(){} };
explanation: Yes, this creates an anonymous inner class that implements the interface.

title: Array Initialization
explanation: Do not specify the dimension when initializing with values. Use `new int[] {1, 2, ...}`.

title: Default Method
description: Must default methods have a body?
explanation: Yes, `default` methods in interfaces must provide a body.

title: Class Literal
explanation: It's `String.class`, not a method call `String.class()`.

title: Short Circuit
explanation: Yes, `&&` short-circuits. If the left side is false, the right side is not evaluated.

title: Variable Shadowing
description: Find the (potential) error - actually just logic.
explanation: Java does not allow redeclaring a variable `x` in a child block if it's already defined in the parent method scope.

title: Final Parameter
explanation: Yes, `final` parameters cannot be modified within the method.

title: Null Case
explanation: Switching on `null` throws a `NullPointerException` at runtime.

title: Inheritance Private
codeSnippet: class A { private int x; } class B extends A {}
explanation: Technically NO/YES nuance. They are not *accessible*, but they exist in the object layout. Question 'Are they inherited?' usually means 'Are they members of subclass?'. Java spec says they are NOT inherited. So `false`. However, the code snippet is correct. The `isCodeCorrect` field refers to the syntax. `isCodeCorrect: true`.

title: String Equality Logic
description: Identify the logical flaw in condition.
explanation: Comparing usage of `==` for Strings checks reference identity. Input from external sources (Scanner, etc.) will result in a new String object, making `==` false. Use `.equals()`.

title: Static Block
description: Does static block run before main?
codeSnippet: class Main { static { System.out.println("Static"); } public static void main(String[] a){} }
explanation: Yes, static blocks are executed when the class is loaded, which happens before `main` is executed.

title: Access Static via Instance
explanation: `sleep` is a static method of `Thread`. Calling it on an instance `t` suggests it sleeps thread `t`, but it actually sleeps the *current* thread. It's a static access warning/error.

title: Abstract Class Constructor
explanation: Yes, abstract classes can have constructors, which are called when concrete subclasses are instantiated.

title: Concurrent Modification
explanation: Modifying a list while iterating over it with an enhanced for-loop throws `ConcurrentModificationException`. Use `Iterator.remove()`.

title: Method Hiding
codeSnippet: class A { static void run(){} } class B extends A { static void run(){} }
explanation: Static methods are hidden, not overridden. The code is correct, but the behavior is hiding (compile-time binding), not polymorphism.

title: Integer Cache Comparison
codeSnippet:
Integer a = 1000; Integer b = 1000;
if (a == b) { }
explanation: `a == b` compares references. For numbers outside the cache range (-128 to 127), this returns `false` even if values are equal. Use `.equals()`.

title: Cloneable Interface
explanation: Yes, code is correct. To answer question: No, `Cloneable` is a marker interface with no methods. `clone()` comes from Object.

title: Final Array Modification
explanation: This code is valid! `final` reference means `arr` cannot point to another array, but the *contents* can be modified. Is there an error? No. Let's make one. `arr = new int[3];`.

title: Reassign Final Reference
codeSnippet:
final int[] arr = {1, 2};
arr = new int[3];
explanation: You cannot reassign a `final` variable to a new object/array.

title: Protected Member Access
description: Can subclass access protected member of another instance?
codeSnippet:
class A { protected int x; } 
class B extends A { void test(A a) { a.x = 10; } }
explanation: Subtle rule: `protected` members are accessible in subclasses *only via inheritance* (i.e., `this.x` or `super.x` or on an instance of `B`). `B` cannot access `protected` member `x` on an instance of `A` (if A is in different package). Assuming different package for strictness. If same package, it works. Usually treated as false for strict encapsulation.

title: Swallow Exception
explanation: Empty catch block swallows the exception, hiding bugs. At least log it.

title: TreeSet Null
description: Can you add null to TreeSet?
explanation: No, `TreeSet` throws `NullPointerException` when adding null (since Java 7), as it tries to compare it.

title: Raw Type Usage
explanation: Using raw types bypasses type safety. Runtime `ClassCastException` because String cannot be cast to Integer.

title: Wait Notify
explanation: Yes, `wait()` throws `IllegalMonitorStateException` if called without holding the object's monitor (not inside synchronized block).

title: Thread Run vs Start
explanation: Calling `run()` executes the code in the *current* thread, not a new one. Use `start()`.

title: Singleton Pattern
explanation: Yes, a single-element Enum is the preferred way to implement a thread-safe Singleton in Java.

title: Map Key Mutability
explanation: Mutable keys (like `StringBuilder` or list) are dangerous. Changing the key changes its hash code, making it irretrievable from the Map.

title: StringBuilder Thread Safety
explanation: No, `StringBuilder` is not synchronized/thread-safe. Use `StringBuffer` for thread safety (though rarely needed).

title: Stream Consumption
explanation: Streams cannot be reused once operated upon (terminal operation `forEach`). This throws `IllegalStateException`.

title: Optional Get
explanation: No, calling `get()` on an empty Optional throws `NoSuchElementException`. Use `orElse` or `ifPresent`.

title: Equals Not Reciprocal
explanation: Violates `equals` contract (must check type, cast, state). Returning `true` makes everything equal, breaking Sets/Maps.

title: Default Constructor visibility
explanation: Yes, strict rule: the default constructor has the same access modifier as the class (public class -> public constructor).

title: BigDecimal Constructor
explanation: Using `double` constructor results in unpredictable precision (0.1000000000005...). Use String constructor `new BigDecimal("0.1")`.

title: Inner Class Static Members
description: Can inner class have static members?
codeSnippet: class Outer { class Inner { static int x; } }
explanation: No, (before Java 16) inner classes could not have static members unless they were constant variables (`static final`). Java 16+ allows it. Assuming standard/older Java interview context: False. Or strict modern: True. Let's stick to 'False' as classic caveat or clarify.

title: Variable Hiding
codeSnippet:
class A { int x = 1; }
class B extends A { int x = 2; }
explanation: Not a syntax error, but `B.x` hides `A.x` (shadowing). It doesn't override. Accessing via `A` reference gets 1, via `B` gets 2. Often a bug.

title: String Split
explanation: Yes, `split` takes a regex. However, `.` matches any character, so this returns an empty array, which is likely a logic bug, but correct compilation.

title: List Remove Index vs Object
explanation: `remove(int)` removes by index. `remove(Object)` removes by value. `list.remove(1)` removes index 1 (value 2), not value 1. Use `remove(Integer.valueOf(1))`.

title: Double NaN
explanation: Correct syntax. Evaluates to `false`. `NaN != NaN`.

title: Resource Leak
explanation: Stream is not closed. Either call `close()` in `finally` or use try-with-resources.

title: CompareTo Contract
description: Must compareTo be consistent with equals?
explanation: It strictly *should* be consistent, but not enforcing it doesn't break compilation. However, sorted collections (TreeSet) will behave weirdly if inconsistent. 'isCodeCorrect: true' as it compiles.

title: Date Mutability
explanation: `java.util.Date` is mutable. Returning a direct reference allows the caller to modify the internal state of `obj`. Return a copy/clone.

title: Arrays AsList
explanation: No, `Arrays.asList` returns a fixed-size list backed by the array. Adding elements throws `UnsupportedOperationException`.

title: Non-Atomic Volatile
codeSnippet:
volatile int count = 0;
public void inc() { count++; }
explanation: `count++` is not atomic. Even with `volatile`, race conditions occur. Use `AtomicInteger`.

title: System Exit
explanation: Syntax is correct. But `finally` block is NOT executed if JVM exits.

title: Class ForName
explanation: `Class.forName` throws `ClassNotFoundException` (checked). Must be handled or declared.

title: String Intern
codeSnippet: String s1 = new String("a"); String s2 = s1.intern();
explanation: Yes, `intern()` returns the canonical representation from the string pool.

title: Iterator Remove
explanation: `remove()` must be called *after* `next()`. Calling it before `next()` (or twice) throws `IllegalStateException`.

title: InstanceOf Interface
explanation: Yes, checks if the object's class implements the interface.

title: Synchronized Constructor
explanation: Constructors cannot be marked `synchronized`. You can synchronize code *inside* them, but the method itself cannot be.

title: Reflection Private
explanation: Yes, `setAccessible(true)` suppresses access checks, allowing access to private members.

title: Notify vs NotifyAll
description: Identify the risk (not syntax error) - logic.
explanation: Using `notify()` wakes only *one* thread. In many cases (condition queues), `notifyAll()` is safer to prevent stuck threads.

title: Daemon Thread
description: Does JVM wait for daemon threads?
explanation: No, JVM exits when the only remaining threads are daemon threads. It does not wait for them.

title: Shift Operator
explanation: `>>` is arithmetic shift (preserves sign). `-1 >> 1` remains `-1`. Use `>>>` for logical shift (fill with zeros).

title: Enum Constructor
explanation: No, Enum constructors are implicitly `private`. You cannot make them `public` or `protected`.

title: Return Type Covariance
codeSnippet:
class A { int get(){return 1;} }
class B extends A { long get(){return 1L;} }
explanation: `long` is not a subtype of `int`. Primitive return types must be identical when overriding. Only reference types can be covariant.

title: Local Class Visibility
description: Is local class visible outside method?
explanation: Snippet is valid. Logic: No, it is not visible. It is scoped to the method block.

title: Stream to Map Duplicate
explanation: Duplicate keys ('a') in `toMap` throw `IllegalStateException`. Provide a merge function `(v1, v2) -> v1`.

title: WeakReference
explanation: No, `WeakReference` does not prevent the object from being garbage collected if no strong references exist.

title: Lambda Variable Capture
explanation: Local variables captured in lambdas must be effective final. Since `x` is reassigned, it is not effective final.

title: Method Reference
explanation: Yes, `ArrayList::new` is a valid method reference for a constructor.

title: Abstract Method Private
explanation: Abstract methods cannot be `private`. They must be overridable by subclasses.

title: Variable Arity Parameter
explanation: Yes, varargs (`...`) allow passing zero or more arguments. If zero, an empty array is passed.

title: Interface Constructor
explanation: Interfaces cannot have constructors.

title: Final Variable Initialization
description: Must final fields be initialized inline?
codeSnippet: class A { final int x; A() { x = 1; } }
explanation: No, they can be initialized in the constructor (blank final).

title: Static Method Override
codeSnippet:
class A { static void run() {} }
class B extends A { @Override static void run() {} }
explanation: Static methods cannot be overridden (only hidden), so `@Override` annotation generates a compile error.

title: Anonymous Interface
codeSnippet: Runnable r = new Runnable() { public void run() {} };
explanation: Yes, this syntax creates an anonymous class implementing the interface.

title: CompareTo Return
codeSnippet: public boolean compareTo(Object o) { return true; }
explanation: `compareTo` must return an `int`, not a `boolean`.

title: Package Private Access
description: Is default access stricter than protected?
explanation: Yes, default (package-private) is stricter than `protected`. Protected allows subclasses in other packages access.

title: Generic Type Instantiation
explanation: You cannot instantiate a generic type parameter `T` directly (`new T()`) due to type erasure.

title: Exception in Static Block
description: Can static block throw checked exception?
explanation: No, static initializers cannot throw checked exceptions unless caught internally.

title: Primitive Null
explanation: Primitive types (`int`) cannot be assigned `null`. Use dependency wrapper `Integer`.

title: Transient Method
explanation: No, the `transient` keyword applies only to variables (fields), not methods.

title: Volatile Array
explanation: Valid code, but often a logical error. `volatile` on an array applies to the reference `arr`, not its elements. `arr[0]` is not volatile.

title: Volatile Local
explanation: Local variables cannot be `volatile`. Only fields can be.

title: Synchronization on Class
description: Can you synchronize on a class literal?
explanation: Yes, this synchronizes on the `Class` object associated with `MyClass`, effectively a global lock for that class loader.

title: Super Access
explanation: Java doesn't support `super.super` to bypass the immediate parent.

title: Generic Wildcard
explanation: No, you cannot add elements (except `null`) to a `List<?>` because the type is unknown.

title: Throw without Throws
explanation: `Exception` is a checked exception. It must be declared in `throws` clause.

title: Default Interface Method Override
codeSnippet:
interface A { default void run(){} } 
class B implements A { public void run(){} }
explanation: Yes, classes can override default interface methods.

title: Static Class Member
explanation: Non-static inner classes cannot have static members (unless constant). `Inner` should be `static class Inner`.

title: Char vs String
explanation: No, you cannot compare primitive `char` with object `String` using `==`.

title: Enum Abstract Method
explanation: If an enum has an abstract method, each constant must implement it: `A { void run(){} }`.

title: Loop Scope
codeSnippet:
for(int i=0; i<10; i++);
int k = i;
explanation: No, variable `i` is scoped to the loop and not visible afterwards.

title: Unreachable Catch
explanation: Valid! NPE is subclass of RE. This order is correct (subclass first). Error: `catch(Exception)` then `catch(IOException)`.

title: Unreachable Catch Order
explanation: `NullPointerException` is a `RuntimeException`. It has already been caught by the first block. Unreachable code.

title: Array Store Exception
description: Does ArrayStore happen at compile time?
explanation: The code *compiles* (arrays are covariant), but throws `ArrayStoreException` at runtime.

title: Import Static
explanation: You must import a member or `*`. `import static java.lang.Math.*;` or `Math.PI`.

title: Protected Class
description: Can a top-level class be protected?
explanation: No, top-level classes can only be `public` or package-private (no modifier).

title: Break to Method
explanation: You cannot `break` out of a method. Use `return`.

title: Assert Keyword
explanation: Code is correct syntax. Question about behavior: No, strictly assertions are disabled by default (run with `-ea`).

title: Generic Static Field
explanation: Static members cannot refer to the class's generic type parameter `T`, because static members are shared across all instances (all T types).

title: Interface Constants
explanation: Yes, fields in interfaces are implicitly `public static final`.

title: Super in Static
explanation: `super` refers to the parent object instance. It cannot be used in a static context.

title: Package Info
explanation: Yes, `package-info.java` is used for package-level documentation and annotations.

title: Main Throws
description: Find the signature handling - actually valid.
codeSnippet: public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {}
explanation: Valid! Main can throw exceptions. Error: `void main()` (no args).

title: Main Args
explanation: Standard main method must take String array arguments `String[] args`.

title: Immutable Collection
explanation: No, `List.of` returns an immutable list. Adding throws `UnsupportedOperationException`.

title: Local Interface
explanation: Interfaces cannot be declared locally inside methods (before Java 16/15).

title: Enum Switch
description: Do you use Enum name in case?
explanation: No, in a switch on an Enum, you use the constant name directly (`case RED:`), not the qualified name (`Color.RED`).

title: Foreach Null
codeSnippet:
List<String> l = null;
for(String s : l) {}
explanation: Iterating over `null` throws `NullPointerException`.

title: Functional Interface
description: Can functional interface have Object methods?
codeSnippet: @FunctionalInterface interface A { void run(); String toString(); }
explanation: Yes, methods from `Object` (like `toString`) do not count against the single abstract method limit.

title: Throws RuntimeException
explanation: Valid code. declaring usage of unchecked exception is allowed but unnecessary. Error: `throw new Throwable()` without declaration.

title: Throw Throwable
explanation: `Throwable` is a checked type (parent of Exception). It must be declared in `throws`.

title: Constructor Recursion
explanation: No, recursive constructor invocation causes a compile-time error.

title: Interface Private Method Access
explanation: Private interface methods are not inherited or accessible by implementing classes.

title: Abstract Static Method
explanation: No, `abstract` implies overriding, and `static` implies no overriding. They conflict.

title: Final Try
explanation: The block is `finally`, not `final`.

title: Double Brace Init
explanation: Yes, it creates an anonymous subclass with an instance initializer block.

title: New Abstract
explanation: `Number` is an abstract class.

title: Interface Properties
explanation: No, interfaces can only have constant (static final) fields, not instance state.

title: Byte Promotion
explanation: Arithmetic on bytes calls for promotion to `int`. `b * 2` is an `int`. Assigning `int` to `byte` requires a cast.

title: System Properties
explanation: Yes, `user.home` is a standard system property.

title: Static Import Class
explanation: `import static` is for members (fields/methods). Importing a class (`Collections`) requires standard `import`.

title: Var Type
explanation: No, `var` cannot infer type from `null` alone. It needs a concrete type context.

title: Unsafe Varargs
explanation: Returning generic varargs array is unsafe effectively (heap pollution risk if casted). Use `@SafeVarargs` if ensuring safety, but generally dangerous.

title: Double Check Locking
codeSnippet: if (inst == null) synchronized(C.class) { if (inst==null) inst=new C(); }
explanation: Strictly No, unless `inst` is declared `volatile`. Without `volatile`, instruction reordering can cause other threads to see partially initialized object.

title: Future Get Blocking
explanation: `f.get()` blocks the current thread until the task completes, potentially freezing the UI. Use `isDone()` or simpler implementation or `CompletableFuture`.

title: CompletableFuture Exception
explanation: Code is correct. Logic: No, `join()` throws unchecked `CompletionException` (wrapping the cuase), unlike `get()` which throws checked `ExecutionException`.

title: Stream Close
explanation: `Files.lines` returns a stream that encapsulates a file channel. It MUST be closed, preferably in a try-with-resources blocks.

title: ThreadLocal Memory Leak
explanation: Yes, if not removed (`tl.remove()`), values stay in the Thread's map, potentially leaking classloaders in web containers.

title: Atomic Reference Field
codeSnippet:
AtomicInteger i = new AtomicInteger(0);
i = new AtomicInteger(1); // Reassigning reference
explanation: Reassigning the `AtomicInteger` reference itself is not thread-safe or atomic. You should update the value *inside* using `set()` or `compareAndSet()`.

title: PhantomReference
explanation: Yes, `PhantomReference.get()` always returns `null` because the object is already phantom reachable (finalized but not reclaimed).

title: Parallel Stream Order
explanation: `forEach` on a parallel stream does not guarantee order. The output will be non-deterministic (e.g. 3142). Use `forEachOrdered`.

title: LinkedHashMap Order
explanation: Yes, setting `accessOrder` to `true` makes iteration order based on access (LRU), not insertion.

title: Executors CachedThreadPool
codeSnippet:
ExecutorService es = Executors.newCachedThreadPool();
// submitting thousands of short tasks
explanation: `CachedThreadPool` creates new threads as needed without bound. High load can cause `OutOfMemoryError` (unable to create native thread).

title: Classloader Delegation
explanation: Yes, the standard delegation model asks the parent classloader to load the class first.

title: Inner Class Serialization
explanation: Inner classes are hard to serialize robustly because they capture the enclosing instance (which must also be serializable) and synthetic field names vary.

title: Security Manager
explanation: Yes, `SecurityManager` is deprecated for removal in recent Java versions (Java 17+).

title: Equals Class Cast
explanation: Must check `instanceof` before casting. If `o` is of different type (or null), this throws `ClassCastException`.

title: StackOverflowError
explanation: Yes, it is an `Error` (subclass of Throwable) so it can be caught, though usually recovery is impossible.

title: Wait in Loop
explanation: Always wait in a loop (`while(condition) wait()`) to handle spurious wakeups.

title: ReentrantLock Fair
explanation: No, default constructor creates a non-fair lock for performance. Use `new ReentrantLock(true)` for fairness.

title: Map ComputeIfAbsent
explanation: Modifying the map inside `computeIfAbsent` block usually throws `ConcurrentModificationException` or corrupts map (undefined behavior).

title: Modules
explanation: No, you can still use the classpath (unnamed module) without `module-info.java`.

title: SimpleDateFormat Thread Safety
codeSnippet:
static SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy");
// usage in threads
explanation: `SimpleDateFormat` is not thread-safe. Shared static instance will cause data corruption. Use `DateTimeFormatter` (Java 8+) or `ThreadLocal`.

title: Variable Handles
explanation: Yes, `VariableHandles` (Java 9) are usually as efficient as usage of `Unsafe` and faster than Reflection.

title: HashCode Mutable Field
codeSnippet: class Key { int id; public int hashCode(){ return id; } }
explanation: If fields used in `hashCode` are mutable, the object's hash bucket might change after modification, but the map won't know, causing memory leaks/lost entries.

title: Checked Exception Functional
explanation: No, standard functional interfaces (`Runnable`, `Consumer`) do not declare checked exceptions. You must catch them or use custom functional interface.

title: Sublist Casting
codeSnippet:
ArrayList<Integer> l = new ArrayList<>();
ArrayList<Integer> sub = (ArrayList<Integer>) l.subList(0, 1);
explanation: `subList` returns a private inner class (e.g. `java.util.RandomAccessSubList`), not `ArrayList`. Casting throws `ClassCastException`.

title: Reference Queue
explanation: No, it's optional. You provide it if you want to be notified when the object is cleared.

title: Enum Singleton Serialization
codeSnippet: enum Singleton { INSTANCE; private Object readResolve() { ... } }
explanation: Enums have special serialization handling by JVM. `readResolve` is ignored (and `writeObject`/`readObject`). Defining them suggests misunderstanding.

title: Interface Static Method
codeSnippet: interface A { static void run(){} } class B implements A {}
explanation: Snippet compiles. Logic: No, static methods in interfaces are NOT inherited by implementing classes. You must call `A.run()`.

title: Monitor State
explanation: Called `notify()` without being synchronized on `o`. Throws `IllegalMonitorStateException`.

title: Records
explanation: Yes, `record` classes (Java 14/16+) are implicitly `final`.

title: Pattern Matching Switch
explanation: Switch expressions on patterns must be exhaustive. `Object` can be other things. Missing `default` clause.

title: Sealed Classes
description: Must permits be in same file?
codeSnippet: sealed class Is permits A, B {}
explanation: No/Yes condition: If in named module, same module. If unnamed module, same package. Code compiles.

title: Lambda Ambiguity
explanation: Compiler cannot infer which interface the lambda targets because both match the functional signature. Casting is required.

title: Text Block Indentation
explanation: Yes, incidental whitespace is stripped based on the position of the closing delimiter or the leftmost non-white char.

title: Method Handle Access
explanation: `publicLookup()` has restricted capabilities. It cannot access package-private or private members, unlike `lookup()`.

title: String Deduplication
explanation: No, G1 GC String Deduplication usually requires a flag `-XX:+UseStringDeduplication`.

title: Stream Reduce Identity
explanation: The identity value (`100`) must be an identity for the accumulator (0 for addition). Using 100 adds 100 *per split* in parallel stream, yielding wrong result.

title: System HashCode
explanation: No, it returns the hash code as if `hashCode()` wasn't overridden (memory address based usually).

title: Optional Serializable
codeSnippet: class A implements Serializable { Optional<String> o; }
explanation: `Optional` is NO Serializable. Fields of type `Optional` in a Serializable class will cause `NotSerializableException`.

title: JIT Compilation
description: Does JIT run on all methods?
explanation: No, JIT compiles 'hot spots' (frequently called methods) to native code, interpreting others.

title: Var Uninitialized
explanation: `var` requires an explicit initializer to infer the type.

title: Switch Expression Yield
explanation: Yes (restricted identifier). `yield` returns a value from a switch expression block.

title: Raw Iterator
explanation: `new ArrayList()` creates a raw `ArrayList`. Its iterator is `Iterator` (raw), not `Iterator<String>`. Unchecked assignment.

title: Collection RemoveIf
explanation: Generally No (for ArrayList). It iterates and removes. For `CopyOnWriteArrayList`, it operates on snapshot/lock.

title: Wildcard Capture
explanation: Compiler cannot prove type safety because `?` (captured) implies unknown type. `l.get(0)` is `Cap#1` but `l.set` expects `Cap#1`. Compiler often rejects this without a helper method.

title: Primitive Wrapper Identity
explanation: Valid code. Result is `false` (different objects).

title: Finalize Deprecation
explanation: `finalize()` is deprecated for removal (Java 9/18). Use `Cleaner` or `PhantomReference`.

title: CompletableFuture AllOf
explanation: No, `allOf` returns `CompletableFuture<Void>`. You must manually inspect individual futures for results.

title: Stream Foreach Modify
explanation: If the stream is parallel, adding to a non-thread-safe collection (`result`) causes data loss or exceptions. Use `collect()`.

title: Method Parameter Reflection
explanation: Yes, but they are generic (`arg0`) unless compiled with `-parameters` flag.

title: Module Private Export
explanation: You cannot export private packages. `exports` makes a package public to other modules. Internal implementations should be `opens` or not exported.

title: ServiceLoader Singleton
explanation: No, `ServiceLoader` creates a new loader instance each time. It is lazy.

title: Lambda Serialization
codeSnippet:
Serializable s = (Runnable & Serializable) () -> System.out.println("Hi");
// Serializing s
explanation: While this syntax requests a serializable lambda, serialization of lambdas is fragile and discouraged as it depends on compiler implementation details.

title: Interface Static Block
explanation: No, interfaces cannot have static initialization blocks.

title: ConcurrentHashMap Null
codeSnippet:
Map<String, String> map = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
map.put(key, null);
explanation: `ConcurrentHashMap` does not allow `null` keys or values. Throws `NullPointerException`.

title: Future Cancel
explanation: No/Yes nuance: It calls `interrupt()` on the thread. The thread must check `Thread.interrupted()` to actually stop. Does not force stop.

title: Generic Array Creation
explanation: Cannot create generic array `new T[...]` because `T` is erased at runtime. Use `Array.newInstance()` with class token.

title: Spliterator Parallel
explanation: Yes, `trySplit()` is the mechanism used to partition the stream for parallel execution.

title: Enum Abstract Class Extension
codeSnippet:
abstract class Base {}
enum E extends Base { A }
explanation: Enums cannot extend other classes (they already extend `Enum`). They can only implement interfaces.

title: Cleaner vs Finalizer
explanation: Yes, `Cleaner` (Java 9) is lighter weight and avoids issues like object resurrection.

title: Module Cycles
codeSnippet:
module A { requires B; }
module B { requires A; }
explanation: Cyclic dependencies between modules are not allowed at compile time.

title: Var Null Assignment
description: Can you assign null to var after init?
explanation: Yes, `s` is inferred as `String` (reference type), so it can hold `null`.

title: Stream Infinite Loop
explanation: `distinct()` stores seen elements. Loop alternates 0, 1. After finding 0 and 1, `distinct` keeps waiting for a new value forever. Infinite loop/hang.

title: Local Class Static Member
description: Can local class have static members (Java 16+)?
codeSnippet: void m() { class L { static int x; } }
explanation: Yes, Java 16+ allows static members in inner/local classes.

title: Annotation Invalid Type
explanation: Annotation members must be primitives, String, Class, enums, annotations, or arrays thereof. `Object` is not allowed.

title: Interface Private Static
description: Can interface have private static methods?
codeSnippet: interface A { private static void run() {} }
explanation: Yes, allowed since Java 9, useful for sharing code between static methods.

title: Method Reference Ambiugity
explanation: `Integer::toString` refers to both static `toString(int)` and instance `toString()`. If target functional interface matches both (e.g. `Function<Integer,String>`), it works. If ambiguous context, error.

title: Try Finally Return
explanation: Yes, `return` in `finally` discards the exception or return value from `try` block. Returns 2.

title: Functional Interface Method Count
codeSnippet:
@FunctionalInterface
interface A { void run(); void stop(); }
explanation: `@FunctionalInterface` ensures strictly one abstract method. Two abstract methods `run` and `stop` cause compilation error.

title: Thread Interruption
explanation: Snippet is correct code. Logic: No, it just sets a flag. The thread must cooperate.

title: Module Opens Failure
codeSnippet:
// Module A does not open pkg to B
// Module B tries setAccessible(true) on A's pkg
explanation: In Java 9+ modules, `setAccessible(true)` fails (`InaccessibleObjectException`) if the package is not `opens` to the caller module.

title: Var Keyword Fields
description: Can you use var for fields?
explanation: No, `var` is only for local variable type inference.

title: New Enum
explanation: Wait, `Enum` constructor is protected but you cannot call it directly or subclass `Enum` explicitly. Only `enum` keyword creates enums.

title: String Format
description: Does format throw exception on mismatch?
explanation: Syntax correct. Logic: Yes, throws `IllegalFormatConversionException` at runtime.

title: Record Mutability
explanation: Record fields are final. `this.x = x` is invalid assignment to final variable.

title: Yield Context
explanation: No, `yield` is only valid inside a switch expression.

title: List Of Null
explanation: `List.of` and other unmodifiable factory methods do not allow `null` elements. Throws `NullPointerException`.

title: Lambda This
description: Does 'this' in lambda refer to lambda instance?
explanation: Snippet valid (in instance method). Logic: No, `this` refers to the enclosing class instance, not the lambda object.

title: Optional Field
explanation: Using `Optional` for fields is generally considered an anti-pattern (not serializable, memory overhead). Intended for return types.

title: Parallel Sort Stability
explanation: No/Yes nuance: The spec says it uses a stable sort (usually Timsort variations). Actually, generally YES for objects.

title: Map Entry Set Modification
explanation: Modifying map during entrySet iteration via the map reference causes CME. Use `Iterator.remove()`.

title: Volatile Double
explanation: Yes, `volatile` guarantees atomic reads/writes for `long` and `double` (which might otherwise be torn on 32-bit systems).

title: Stream FindAny vs FindFirst
explanation: Valid code. `findAny()` is explicitly non-deterministic in parallel streams. If you need the first element, use `findFirst()` (costlier). Not error, but distinct semantic.

title: Null switch label
explanation: Prior to modern Java versions (17+ preview), `case null` was a syntax error. In modern Java, it is valid!

title: Generic Exception Catch
description: Can you catch generic exception T?
explanation: No, you cannot catch a type parameter `T`. Exception types must be known at compile time.

title: Thread Stop
explanation: `Thread.stop()` is deprecated and unsafe because it releases locks immediately, leaving objects in inconsistent states.

title: CopyOnWriteArrayList
explanation: Yes, `CopyOnWriteArrayList` iterator relies on a snapshot of the array at creation time. It does not reflect subsequent additions.

title: Record Compact Constructor
explanation: This is a canonical constructor, not compact. For compact, remove args: `R { ... }`. If canonical, assignments to fields are required but might be cleaner. `this.x = x` is valid.

title: Record Field Assignment
explanation: In a compact constructor, you cannot assign to `this.x`. You modify the parameter `x`, and it is assigned automatically at the end.

title: Abstract Enum
explanation: No, you cannot explicitly declare an enum `abstract`, though constants can implement abstract methods.

title: Generic InstanceOf
explanation: Cannot check instantiation of generic type with arguments (`List<String>`) due to erasure. Use `List<?>` or `List`.

title: Stream Reuse
description: Can stream be saved and used later?
explanation: Yes, but it can only be consumed once.

title: Synchronized Value Based Class
explanation: Synchronizing on value-based classes (`Integer`, `Double`, etc.) is deprecated for removal and unsafe (due to caching/pooling/future Project Valhalla changes).

title: Module Requires Transitive
explanation: Yes, `requires transitive` means any module requiring the current module also implicitly requires `mod.b`.

title: Reflection Final Field
codeSnippet:
f.setAccessible(true);
f.set(obj, val); // f is static final
explanation: Modifying `static final` fields via reflection often fails (especially in modern Java) or doesn't work if the value was inlined by compiler (constants).

title: Interface Main Method
codeSnippet: interface A { public static void main(String[] a){} }
explanation: Yes, interfaces can have static methods, including `main`, allowing them to be execution entry points.

title: Nested Try-With-Resources Var
explanation: Resource `r` is scoped to the `try` block and is not visible in `catch` or `finally`.

title: Static Method Interface Ref
description: Can you call static method via instance?
codeSnippet: A a = new Impl(); a.staticMethod(); // A is interface
explanation: No, static methods in interfaces can ONLY be called via the interface name (`A.staticMethod()`), not via instance variables.

title: Duplicate Annotation
explanation: Annotations are not repeatable by default. Unless `@Test` is meta-annotated with `@Repeatable`, this is an error.

title: Strictfp Interface
explanation: Yes, `strictfp` can be applied to interfaces.

title: Stream Peek Side Effect
explanation: Using `peek` for side effects (modifying state) is discouraged and dangerous if the stream is parallel or if the operation is optimized away.

title: Local Enum
explanation: Yes, Java 16+ allows local enums.
